captions.text:
NARRATOR:
From the director of all those Russell Crowe

movies you never saw. And the writer of LOST’s
unsatisfying final episode. Comes a sort-of

prequel that doesn’t use the best parts
of the Alien franchise. Prometheus. A film

whose first 30 minutes are mostly landscape
shots. Where two scientists are on a quest

to find extraterrestrial life based on really
flimsy evidence. A trillion-dollar mission

manned by the worst crew in space. A lazy
captain, who leaves his crew to die. A stoner

geologist with state of the art computer maps,
radio communication, mapping balls, and GPS.

MILLBURN:
We are at 7401477, why?

NARRATOR:
Who still gets lost. An inconsistent biologist
who is scared of a 2000 year old dead body,

MILLBURN:
No, ship’s good.

NARRATOR:
but falls in love with clearly dangerous alien
snake.

MILLBURN:
Hey, baby.

NARRATOR:
And an idiot woman who can only run in straight

lines. A film with so much CGI, the visual
effects department forgot to change anyone’s

heart rate. One man will achieve his lifelong
dream of finding aliens but somehow feels

like a failure after only investigating for
6 hours. And one woman will give forced exposition.

SHAW:
I can’t create life.

NARRATOR:
And will create life

DAVID:
You’re pregnant.

NARRATOR
And get her uterus cut open which will hurt

a lot during standing, but not jumping, falling
or repelling. A film so forced, it attempts

to connect to the Alien franchise by having
someone drink a drop of black goo then impregnate

our main character with an squid baby which
impregnates an engineer which creates an alien

that only kinda looks like the aliens in the
real movies even though they already showed

a picture of that queen alien on a wall. An
epic quest that has no answers or payoff to

anything, like: The green goo. The giant head
statue. The disregard of evolution. This green

crystal. The engineers’ hatred of humans.
The black goo. The black goo creating an eye

worm. The black goo creating a zombie. The
black goo dissolving an engineer. The reason

why people in the holograms are running into
a room full of black goo. David murdering

someone for no reason. The engineers leaving
ancient humans maps to their weapons facilities.

And why it matters he was Vicker’s dad.
Starring: Noomi Rapeface, Data, Dr. Manhattan,

Black Oil from The X-Files, Charlie The Ron,
Benjamin Button and Super Vagina. Prometheus.

God, please just stay away from Blade Runner.
Check out our new Screenjunkies episode on

how not to get taken, or else I’ll take
you. I have a very particular set of skills.

As always, leave a comment with the movie
you’d like to see next time, or a word you’d

like to hear me say in my sweet voice. Hello
Jovem Nerd. What what in the butt. The dude

abides. Fuzzy wuzzy was a bear. Fuzzy wuzzy
had no hair. Fuzzy wuzzy wasn’t very fuzzy,
was he?

comments.author: firestonegraywolf

comments.text:
The biggest flaw of this movie was it's lack of editing. Someone needed to 
approach the writing staff and go, "Ok, the Iranian myths I get, the alien 
Jesus theory, ok, go for it. The idea that your creators are base and 
flawed (and despise you) makes an interesting parallel through most of the 
characters BUT that means you cannot make the film also a mindless slasher. 
Existentialism, science fantasy and random CGI violence/illogic do not mix 
- you cannot go from David's struggle to validate his reality to some guy 
Hulking out and getting set on fire (and alien penis snakes), without an 
actual transition (you also need to relate to the crew). And was the 'on 
the nose aliens as genitals' thing really necessary? Nope.﻿

comments.text:
In the end if the Scott wanted to include space philosophy he shouldn't 
have used someone else's already written script instead make it from 
scratch. I think that is where the divide starts in because fans of Xenos 
wanted to see more Xenos but it was just a plot device not a main story. 
Others who are just general fans of sci-if love it but avid viewers are set 
back by the blunders. Scott has followed the trend with other typical 
directors who take others Ideas or franchises and warp it to there own 
example: remakes/reboots and C grade movies. James Cameron Just directs 
others scripts and always make come to life or writes his own like Avatar.﻿

comments.text:
I knew it was going to be shit when they said something like "This cluster 
of stars was so far away that there's now way these ancient people could 
have seen them" and proof that they'd been visited by aliens. Let's apply 
some SUPER basic logic here. There are, for all intents and purposes, 
infinite stars out there. You could take a hand full of marbles, throw them 
on the ground, and the pattern WILL match some stars out there somewhere. 
there is no pattern of random circles that won't match a star cluster 
somewhere.﻿

comments.text:
I love the original ‘Alien’ franchise, even part 3 and Resurrection. I let 
myself get excited about ‘Prometheus’ when it was first announced, but it 
was a big disappointment. I remember people scoffing and hissing in the 
theater. Ridley Scott's age is showing. I won’t bother seeing the sequel. 
I’m not going to let myself get excited about Neill Blomkamp’s version, 
whatever that may be. ﻿
